text: Nuclear appearance of a factor that binds the <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> response element within the <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhancer correlates with <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .
Activation of T lymphocytes requires the combined signaling of the T cell receptor and costimulatory molecules such as <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The ability of T cells to produce <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is a critical control point in T lymphocyte activation .

The <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhancer contains a functional motif named <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> response element ( CD28RE ) that serves a role as a target for mitogenic T cell activation signals .
The CD28RE sequence reveals similarity to the consensus kappaB binding motif .

Here we demonstrate that CD28RE binds an inducible protein with a molecular mass of approximately 35 kDa called nuclear factor of mitogenic - activated T cells ( NF-MATp35 ) that is clearly different from the known NF - kappaB / Rel family members .

Induction of NF-MATp35 was shown to depend on de novo protein synthesis and was restricted to T cells that received a mitogenic combination of T cell stimuli , not necessarily including <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling .
Nonmitogenic T cell stimulation did not result in appearance of NF-MATp35 .
These results indicate that mitogenic combinations of T cell activation signals are integrated at the level of NF-MATp35 induction .
Similar to its effect on <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production , cyclosporin A inhibited the induction of NF-MATp35 .

text: Taken together , these data demonstrate that the nuclear appearance of NF-MATp35 shows excellent correlation with <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production , which is a unique characteristic among nuclear factors implicated in the control of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression .
